abstract: Google uses a global network of part-time quality raters to help it evaluate proposed changes to its search formulas. But those people don’t directly affect the search results, as Bits wrote Tuesday.
snippet: Google uses a global network of part-time quality raters to help it evaluate proposed changes to its search formulas. But those people don’t directly affect the search results, as Bits wrote Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: My post Tuesday about the role of humans in Google’s search results misinterpreted a comment by Peter Norvig, Google’s head of research. In an interview with Technology Review, Mr. Norvig talked about how the search engine has a vast network of part-time employees evaluating how good its results are. As I read the interview, I incorrectly thought he was saying that human ratings were fed into Google’s algorithms and used, alongside PageRank and other quantitative measures of pages, to determine the order in which sites are listed in response to a given query.

headline.main: Google: There’s Nobody in Our Black Box. Yet.
